image.altText: a woman crying and two young people

items.synopsis: Alina Kauffman, 24, had just picked up her 15-year-old brother, Ernesto Salazer, from his new job and were just metres away from home when their car was struck in Heckenberg near Liverpool.

title.children: 'My kids are gone': Distraught mother of siblings killed in crash in Sydney's south-west visits site

image.altText: the outside of a building

items.synopsis: The museum in Ultimo is set to get a more "modest" rebuild than planned under the former state Coalition government — with only half of the $500 million previously allocated to be spent.

title.children: 'Modest' rebuild of Sydney's Powerhouse Museum 'suits the times'

image.altText: Aunty Susan Anderson sitting with other elders in front of Cabbage Tree Island welcome sign

items.synopsis: Cabbage Tree Island residents, some fifth generation, force their way back onto the river island to protest a decision not to rebuild in the wake of last year's catastrophic floods.

title.children: Indigenous community residents protest decision not to rebuild their island homes after flooding

image.altText: Man in a blue shirt shares a chair with a woman with black hair

items.synopsis: Ex-mayor of defunct Hurstville City Council Philip Sansom said he had been "very surprised" to hear the ICAC had found he engaged in serious corrupt conduct and he was considering his legal options.

title.children: Former mayor 'very surprised' ICAC considered accepting flights from a developer corrupt behaviour

image.altText: Aerial view of a ship cutting a path through ice  towards the camera.

items.synopsis: The Australian, based at the remote Casey Research Station 3,880 km south of Perth, has a "developing medical condition" .

title.children: Urgent evacuation for unwell Australian expeditioner at  Antarctic research station

image.altText: A man looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: While Yevgeny Prigozhin hogged the limelight, Wagner's founder Dmitry Utkin called shots in the shadows — in 2021, he broke the group's golden rule and lawyers saw their chance.

title.children: A terrifying man went down on Prigozhin's plane. In death, Dmitry Utkin's crimes are emerging

image.altText: exterior of the Newcastle courthouse building

items.synopsis: A 42-year-old Port Stephens man is facing seven charges, after allegedly stabbing a NSW police officer who is being treated for facial injuries.

title.children: Newcastle court refuses bail after man allegedly stabs NSW police officer in Port Stephens

image.altText: metal cabinet 2

items.synopsis: A 33-year-old man has faced court charged with being an accessory after the fact to murder, after the discovery of a body earlier this year.

title.children: Man extradited from Queensland to face charges after body found in a metal container

image.altText: The front of a grocery store with English and Thai signage

items.synopsis: Conversations about Haymarket often centre around Chinatown. But just a few streets away, Thai Town is thriving — and it's just received funding injection that could be transformative.

title.children: While Chinatown battles for its soul, this Sydney enclave is booming

image.altText: The Panthers players sit next to the JJ Giltinan minor premiership shield

items.synopsis: Penrith Panthers wrap up back-to-back NRL minor premierships with a dominant victory over North Queensland Cowboys to end their season. Follow all the action, talking points and stats in our live blog of all Saturday's NRL matches.

title.children: Penrith win back-to-back minor premierships, Newcastle put Dragons to the sword early

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A very entertaining half of football that. The Knights looked like they were going to run away in that first half, but the Dragons responded nicely to hit back with that Ben Hunt try. The Knights have edged possession 52 per cent to 48, but the three line breaks to nil is the big factor in why they are on top. All three either led to a try later in the set, or resulted directly in a try being scored. The Dragons' eight errors will need to be cleared up too if they are to get back into the contest - that's double what the Knights have coughed up.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Knights lead Dragons 16-6 at half-time

children.content: A very entertaining half of football that.
The Knights looked like they were going to run away in that first half, but the Dragons responded nicely to hit back with that Ben Hunt try.
The Knights have edged possession 52 per cent to 48, but the three line breaks to nil is the big factor in why they are on top.
All three either led to a try later in the set, or resulted directly in a try being scored.
The Dragons' eight errors will need to be cleared up too if they are to get back into the contest - that's double what the Knights have coughed up.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: So, Simon, what does this mean for the Roosters ? - Old timer. I'm glad you asked, Old timer. That means the Roosters, after their impressive 26-12 victory against Souths last night, will play finals. That's a tremendous result given they were 14th four weeks ago.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Roosters, Raiders, Sharks make finals

children.content: So, Simon, what does this mean for the Roosters ?
I'm glad you asked, Old timer.
Roosters, after their impressive 26-12 victory against Souths last night
That's a tremendous result given they were 14th four weeks ago.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Broncos failure to beat Melbourne at Lang Park on Thursday means they will now face Melbourne in the first week of the finals at Lang Park. That could be bad news for the Broncos. The Storm have not been beaten by the Broncos at Lang Park since 2009 and have a 14-game winning streak.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brisbane to play Melbourne in week one of the finals

children.content: The Broncos failure to beat Melbourne at Lang Park on Thursday means they will now face Melbourne in the first week of the finals at Lang Park.
That could be bad news for the Broncos.
The Storm have not been beaten by the Broncos at Lang Park since 2009 and have a 14-game winning streak.

image.altText: Man holds dirty depleted ammunition

items.synopsis: The weapons use depleted uranium to attack military tanks but have long been opposed by anti-war campaigners who say they create a "long-term health threat".

title.children: Behind the controversial Cold War invention the US is sending to help Ukraine

image.altText: People brave strong winds as Super Typhoon Saola approaches.

items.synopsis: Flights were cancelled and businesses shuttered in Hong Kong ahead of the super typhoon.

title.children: Typhoon Saola kills one after making landfall in China

image.altText: Jimmy Buffett performs in a white jacket playing a blue guitar.

items.synopsis: A social media post confirmed the US singer died "surrounded by his family, friends, music and dogs".

title.children: 'He lived his life like a song until his very last breath': US singer Jimmy Buffett dies, aged 76

image.altText: Man in blue pumps both firsts, one holding tennis racket

items.synopsis: The 23-time grand slam winner defeated fellow Serb Laslo Djere in a nail-biting comeback, making the fourth round of the US open.

title.children: Novak Djokovic digs deep to defeat fellow Serb Laslo Djere

image.altText: Man looks through glass circle

items.synopsis: A Canberra-based defence company is using a high-powered and lethal laser to shoot down drones for the first time on Australian soil.

title.children: 'Good at hitting high-speed targets': Drone-killing laser gives glimpse into future AUKUS projects

image.altText: Chinese flag with cattle

items.synopsis: China imported a record amount of beef in the month of July, with most of it coming from Brazil. But a meat analyst says it could soon become Australia's biggest market.

title.children: China's economy might be slowing, but its appetite for beef is not

image.altText: Composite thumbnail with Hasbulla and Jeremy Rockliff.

items.synopsis: An image of Russian social media star Hasbulla, who has dwarfism, was used in a post on the Tasmanian premier's Instagram page to announce a medical clinic opening — and disability advocates aren't happy.

title.children: Tasmanian premier apologises over Instagram post featuring Hasbulla

image.altText: Varroa mite nestled on a bee, with a blue circle identifying it on the body

items.synopsis: With bees responsible for pollinating much of the food we find at the supermarket and green grocer, authorities remain committed to trying to eradicate the recently introduced varroa mite before it gains too much of a foothold.

title.children: Millions of bees are dead as governments scramble to contain varroa mite, so why is the parasite still such a threat?

image.altText: Television presenter David Attenborough

items.synopsis: When David Attenborough was touring China in 1979, he asked a question about population control. Transcripts show it was one of the first mentions of the One Child Policy to Western media.

title.children: One of China's biggest decisions was a secret from the West. Then David Attenborough asked one question

image.altText: Carlton players celebrate

items.synopsis: Experienced forward Darcy Vescio has kicked three goals as Carlton started a new era under coach Mathew Buck with a narrow AFLW win over Gold Coast, Adelaide thrashes Port in the Showdown and Geelong beat the Western Bulldogs.

title.children: Carlton hang on to win thriller against Gold Coast, Adelaide win Showdown

image.altText: Man wearing a black jacket looking towards the camera.

items.synopsis: Former Queensland Australian of the Year Jon Rouse APM is the man tasked with the new role, in an interim capacity until the end of the financial year, when a permanent appointment will be made.

title.children: The Queensland government has just appointed an interim victims' commissioner. What does that mean?

items.synopsis: When Singapore police raided a suspected money laundering ring last month, they seized property and assets including a collection of about 60 colourful, mostly plastic figurines in the shape of a pot-bellied bear.

title.children: Bearbricks are 'the sweet spot' for criminals looking to launder money, experts say

image.altText: A purple land crab by the road on West Island of the Cocos Keeling Islands

items.synopsis: The Defence Force is about to splash more than $500 million on this remote part of Australia to upgrade the airstrip to take more high-tech spy planes. Locals, already concerned about parts of the islands falling into the sea, are worried what it'll mean for their futures.

title.children: Some 'inconvenient Australians' fear their slice of paradise will be ruined in the name of national security

image.altText: A man in a turban stands in front of a van covered in Indigenous artwork.

items.synopsis: Grassroots initiatives are proving "powerful" to help multicultural Australians decide how to vote in the Voice referendum. And now a date is set, individuals and independent groups are going to great lengths to ensure their communities are informed.

title.children: Grassroots efforts may be the 'powerful' decider for multicultural Australians' Voice vote

image.altText: Men standing in a room with a lot of computers

items.synopsis: Fragments of spent rockets and other debris are clogging up the area above the stratosphere. As tensions ratchet up on Earth, some space agencies fear the next frontier of conflict could be above us.

title.children: Earth's orbit is a trash heap. Here's how that could lead to an unstoppable junk cascade or even a war

image.altText: A jet ski driving on open ocean

items.synopsis: Morocco is investigating the death of a French-Moroccan after he and another Moroccan tourist riding jet skis were shot dead by Algerian coastguards, media reports say.

title.children: Moroccan-French tourists shot after straying into Algerian waters on jet skis

image.altText: An illustration of a giant red creature with grey tentacles walking along a street.

items.synopsis: Tan has won numerous awards and two of his books, a wordless graphic novel The Arrival and Rules of Summer, were recently ranked in the BBC's top 100 children's books of all time.

title.children: ‘I think orcas would have something to say about our religion’: Writer Shaun Tan doesn’t believe in God

image.altText: A man and a woman look at the camera.

items.synopsis: Natalya Kovalchuk fled the outbreak of war in Ukraine early last year with her children and is glad to be together with her family — but some aid groups are warning that Ukrainian refugees are missing out on basic support.

title.children: Natalya's family fled destruction — but advocates say hundreds like her are being left 'in limbo'

image.altText: Objects on the wreck may help identify it

items.synopsis: Detailed 3D maps of the bottom of the Swan River lead maritime archaeologists to a sunken barge in the heart of Perth that has lain unexplored for many years.

title.children: Search for 'lumps and bumps' in Perth's Swan River leads to surprise shipwreck find

image.altText: A drawing of dozens of superheroes

items.synopsis: While Batman fought the Joker, the X-Men were fighting prejudice. And while they've haven't always done it perfectly, fans say X-Men comics have been a place "where anyone can see themselves".

title.children: For 60 years, X-Men comics have tackled themes of racism, homophobia, anti-Semitism and more

image.altText: a woman in a hospital bed overcome with emotion as she holds her newborn

items.synopsis: Almost immediately after an emergency C-section, Adrianna Contoleon was in theatre again — this time for brain surgery.

title.children: 'We wanted to share our love with a child': Mum with spina bifida undergoes multiple surgeries for parenthood dream

image.altText: A man with a beard

items.synopsis: An extreme body modifier who implanted a snowflake shape in a woman's hand, leading to her death, has appealed against his 10-year jail sentence, arguing that consent was not considered during sentencing.

title.children: NSW body modifier appeals against 'excessive' sentence after being found guilty of manslaughter and genital mutilation

image.altText: Two very attractive black women with curly hair, both smiling and wearing black tops, one with a tartan coat

items.synopsis: Africultures is the place to be once a year on a Saturday in Sydney. The festival, which has been running for 15 years, attracts massive crowds.

title.children: Dressed for success: The festival that weaves together fashion, food and music
